pages.text: Often found in ground containing dead biomass, this herb is referred to as a weed due to its immense nutrient intake. The seeds of the plant are common to discover in dirt and mud, but only extremely well-fertilized land will cause them to take root.

Once it has begun to grow, it will absorb the nutrients in the ground surrounding it and quickly sprout its stalks. These stalks are hollow and tube-like, with vibrant green flesh to contrast the pale, flaky skin on the outside.
